data.title: Error Log
data.solution:
<?php
/**
 * Auto-generated code below aims at helping you parse
 * the standard input according to the problem statement.
 **/

$MESSAGE = stream_get_line(STDIN, 1000 + 1, "\n");

// Write an answer using echo(). DON'T FORGET THE TRAILING \n
// To debug: error_log(var_export($var, true)); (equivalent to var_dump)

$pattern = '/in (\/[\w\/.-]+)( on line (\d+))?/';
preg_match($pattern, $MESSAGE, $matches);

if ( @$matches[3]  )
{
    echo( basename($matches[1]). " " .@$matches[3] );   
}
else
{
    echo( basename($matches[1]) );   
}

?>
data.statement:
As a developer, you want to identify all the error lines present in the application. The application provides you with the complete line from the error log file, and it's up to you to extract the file name and the line number of the error, if specified.

• The error message is always in a single line.

• The error message always starts with a <<description>>, followed by the relevant <<file path>> and <<file name>>, and optionally followed by the <<line number>> and/or some <<other information>>.

• The <<description>> may contain other file names, but they are irrelevant for the purpose of this clash.

• The <<file name>> always follows the <<file path>> (which includes various directories ending with a {{/}}) and ends with the extension {{.php}}.

• The <<line number>> follows the words {{on line}}.

data.inputDescription: <<Line 1:>> A string [[MESSAGE]] for the error message to parse
data.outputDescription: <<Line 1:>> If the line number is specified: the file name and the line number separated by a space; otherwise, just the file name

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

As a developer, you want to identify all the error lines present in the application. The application provides you with the complete line from the error log file, and it's up to you to extract the file name and the line number of the error, if specified.

• The error message is always in a single line.

• The error message always starts with a description, followed by the relevant file path and file name, and optionally followed by the line number and/or some other information.

• The description may contain other file names, but they are irrelevant for the purpose of this clash.

• The file name always follows the file path (which includes various directories ending with a /) and ends with the extension .php.

• The line number follows the words on line.
Input
Line 1: A string MESSAGE for the error message to parse
Output
Line 1: If the line number is specified: the file name and the line number separated by a space; otherwise, just the file name
Constraints
Example
Input
PHP Notice:  Undefined index: 0215 in /var/www/file.php on line 199
Output
file.php 199
